subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... Yes. ... On the contrary, when it comes to the execution of the program, compilation is emphatically not a lossy process. If it were, then the program s
messageBody:
On Tuesday, September 30, 2003, at 12:07:31 PM, Jim Dixon wrote:

>> > I know that this is official Sun doctrine. But compilation is always
>> > a lossy process, and the smaller the target instruction set, the more
>> > information you lose. The JVM has a small instruction set. To increment
>> > a variable, you put a 1 on the stack and say "add". Oh my :-(
>>
>> Why does that trouble you?

> Is this a real question??

Yes.

> It's just an example. With a larger instruction set, you can increment
> variables in place, at a lower cost in terms of code size and run time.

> The main point is that compilation is a lossy process. When you write
> i++ it's succinct but very clear. The compiler translates this into
> push variable
> push 1
> add
> store variable
> While it's not impossible, it's difficult and expensive for a bytecode
> (re)compiler to sort out what's going on here and optimize back to the
> succintness of the original. The larger the instruction set, the more
> information preserved in the bytecode, the less difficult and expensive
> the process is.

On the contrary, when it comes to the execution of the program, compilation
is emphatically not a lossy process. If it were, then the program's
behavior would not be what we expect. If it is what we expect, then no
information has been lost.

Ron Jeffries
www.XProgramming.com
Get over it. -- The Eagles
